summary: In the context of EU legal and regulatory frameworks, "soft skills," redirected to the preferred term "non-cognitive skills," encompass a range of interpersonal and intrapersonal competencies essential for effective communication, teamwork, and problem-solving. These skills are increasingly recognized in EU policies aimed at enhancing employability and fostering social inclusion. Non-cognitive skills are vital for adapting to diverse work environments and are often integrated into educational and vocational training programs. The EU emphasizes the development of these skills to support lifelong learning and to address the evolving demands of the labor market, thereby promoting a more resilient and adaptable workforce.
